name: Lorenzo Gilyard
Types of jobs worked:
Trash collector at Deffenbaugh Disposal, 
supervisor for trash collection in Kansas 
(Disposal Service Deffenbaugh )
Employment status during series:
Employed as a supervisor at a trash collection 
company, Deffenbaugh Disposal, since 1986.
Living with: Spouse before arrest for the murders
Method of killing:
Strangled, most victims had pieces of clothing 
stuffed in their mouths and ligature marks on 
their necks. Some of the victims were posed.
How close did killer live?:
Prosecutors believe that he drove to the crime 
scenes
Sentencing:
The prosecution is seeking the death penalty, 
the trial is scheduled for October 2006. On 
August 24, 2006 the defense requested the 
trial be postponed until March 2007.  Gilyard 
is facing ten counts of first-degree murder and 
two counts of capital murder.
Date convicted:
The trial was originally scheduled for October 
2006, however, a motion was made on August 
24, 2006 to postpone the trial until March 5, 
2007 due to budget cuts in the state public 
defender system. The motion was granted. 
Throughout pre-trial hearing attorneys have 
debated several issues surrounding the case, 
including the possibility of eliminating the 
death penalty. A key piece of evidence was 
prematurely destroyed by the Kansas City 
Police Department, a blue coat with blood 
stains. Because of this the defense has 
requested that the prosecutions death penalty 
motion be relinquished. The prosecution is 
seeking multiple trials with the first one solely 
focusing on five killings that occurred 
between 1986 and 1987.
Name and state of prison:
While awaiting trial Gilyard is being held at 
the Missouri Department of Corrections.
